cause.description:
Geneva Convention, 1949:
"No physical or mental torture, nor any other form of coercion, may be inflicted on prisoners of war to secure from them information of any kind whatever. Prisoners of war who refuse to answer may not be threatened, insulted, or exposed to any unpleasant or disadvantageous treatment of any kind."
(http://www.ohchr.org; Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights) ...
The Universal Declaration of Human Rights, 1948:
“No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.”
(http://hrw.org; Human Rights Watch) ...
"Detainee abuse has been widespread. The DAA [Detainee Abuse and Accountability] Project has documented over 330 cases in which U.S. military and civilian personnel are credibly alleged to have abused or killed detainees. These cases involve more than 600 U.S. personnel and over 460 detainees. Allegations have come from U.S. facilities throughout Afghanistan, Iraq and at Guantánamo Bay. (These numbers are conservative and likely lower than the actual number of credible allegations of abuse.)"
(http://hrw.org; Human Rights Watch)
1. The United States must end its use of torture, whether the victims are civilian detainees or military prisoners of war.
cause.mission: Stop the use of torture as a military tactic of the United States.
cause.name: End Torture
